comment: Always request to see the raw data from an experiment

experience: I was close to retirement so it didn’t affect me much but I felt bad for the students on the paper.
comment: Mistakes happen. It is important to retract the paper as soon as the error is detected and all the authors have been made aware. It is very hard on all concerned.

We check accuracy in recording and presentation to the highest standards. Involve the team well and train them for data collection, analysis, and interpretation.
'- Much more checking, and double checking, of codes and against published examples in the literature .

It was an honest mistake, an oversight. I'm glad we caught it as it was a coding error that would, and did, infect several experiments, and even experiments for other labs if they used the code. Retraction was an easy process that was well-handled by the journal.
comment: thanks for doing this important work.

experience: Need to review all the data regardless of the experience of the collaborators
Yes, when receiving reviewer comments we ensure that we make strong rebuttals on comments that we believe are not appropriate.
comment: Biggest lesson learnt is not to do everything that a journal editor and reviewers ask, especially in high ranking journals. I guess we were lucky as we chose to retreat the paper purely based on the fact that what the journal was requesting us to do was simply wrong. Upon reflection we were proud that we stood up for what was right and subsequently we where able to resubmit our original paper with the original appropriate analysis and the paper was published.

experience: NA
comment: the error was caused by data with large numbers of zeroes (for example 180000000 gr for the weight [deleted identifiable information]). It is easy to enter one zero less or more than the correct number. I now express data like this as 180 000 000 in a separate data columnn

experience:
Careful and objective.
Molecular structure should be determined comprehensively from multiple data sources.
NMR, mass spectrometry, X-ray crystallography, IR (compare with literature values and vibrational calculations of similar structures), derivatization (note skeletal changes in derivatization reactions)
Share compound data with group members.
May make multiple mistakes (fundamental problems in the operation).
Do not get caught up in the meritocracy. Do not rush.
When mistakes are made, correct them gracefully. Respond with sincerity. Do not be overly discouraged.
NA
Retraction was unfortunate as there was no scientific error. Each conclusion was supported by 5
comment: The withdrawal process was very stressful as we were confident about scientific authenticity of data but could not provide raw scans though we had autorads. Keeping raw scans for more than 5 years is difficult in LMIC settings. We have started sending pdf of raw scans to journals while submission but most don't take it. We would be relieved if journals checked raw data before publishing as Scientists do not have expertise in. Checking data

experience: I never thought I’d be faced with retraction of an article. Surprisingly it is one of the most challenging things I encountered as a young scientist. While I feared the recourse of obtaining the reputation of being an “untidy scientist,” I believed it necessary given the self-correcting nature of the occupation. Since the retraction, others have confirmed my findings and have provided validation to my corrected report.

It was extremely sad, when we found out about the mistake and had to retract. However, I was very positively surprised how the journal was understanding our situation and gave us a change to resubmit, when we had corrected for the mistake.
comment:
Always check your work multiple times to be sure no mistakes have been made. Especially ask a friend or colleague to go through your work.
mail: [deleted identifiable information]

experience: It would have been very useful if the journals would explain the causes for the error and how to avoid them in the retraction note.
comment: It turns out that copying large datasets in a FASTA format into Excel transposes a few of the lines in the database. it is very difficult to spot since it is a very rare situation.

experience: NA
comment: Instead of retracting, they should have pointed out the mistakes and made us to correct them. Some times, non English speaking persons might  take the expression from other papers but not the data or result. This should be viewed sympathetically.

experience: The journal could have asked to change one figure that was the main issue
comment: Students can not be relied upon blindly

The Devil is in the details. Nobody is perfect. Error will always occur. What you do after an error is identified is crucial. Those never having done an error may never have done anything.
comment:
Good initiative. I have alone been responsible for the output of the [deleted identifiable information] database [deleted identifiable information], including > 50,000 characters of Oracle SQL code. Debugging and quality validation takes > 90% of  working hours. Despite advanced multi step systems to catch errors, sooner or later an error will pass through. I made a complete Oracle filing system for my medical records in cancer genetics > 20 years ago which still lives on, but read in the papers on all governmental efforts failing because they are basically not well enough designed. 
My mail is [deleted identifiable information].
Good luck!

experience: Retraction give me a lot of chance of exploration and improve my skills about research. But, in field of research, other fellows considered you as a criminals. So, Journals should make a excellent peer review platform. So that all the technical mistakes can be removed at that time. Not after the publishing.
NA
It turned out that the results were fitting much better to other published results after we corrected the error. Everybody at the journal was very helpful when I contacted them about the problem.
comment: If your research data is not fitting to other publish data, check the whole calculation process again.

experience: In developing countries, it is difficult to save the raw data in best conditions for long time. The raw scans also can not be saved for long years due to shared computers. The policy in institute/country is to retain data for 5 years but Journals which withdrew our papers asked for data which was 8-20 years old. The old lab itself did not exist. There were no SSD hard drives or google drives in that era. So I felt that journal should have issued a correction and given oprion to upload new scans of old autorads instead of retraction. Moreover why only Scientist is held responsible, The Journal also should have checked the data prior to publishing as they take publication charges
comment: I learnt the lesson in a hard way. Scientifically sound data has no value until you have saved back up until you retire. Prefer to publish in journals which check raw data prior to publishing as Journal is equally responsible

experience: We realized an error while extracting timeseries from the same dataset for a different experiment. The research group unanimously agreed to retract the study, including the Ph.D. student whose thesis relied on that paper. However, I felt upset when discussing the decision to retract the already published study with other colleagues. I heard comments such as, "It's a waste of time," "Your prestige will be affected," and the most interesting one, "Don't do it. Manuscripts follow the evolution theory, and if your results are wrong, they won't be replicated. Consequently, no one will pay attention to them anymore. On the other hand, the retraction was quite fast and easily processed by the journal team.
comment:
Publishing pressure and the wide range of journal options available are impeding scientific progress. It has become challenging to produce replicable and valuable effects given the current context where empiricism lacks realism, and realism lacks consistency and congruency. Researchers may often define phenomena based solely on their own instrumental interpretations without grounding their discoveries in previous stable effects, leading to frequent rediscovery of wheels and aliens. The limitations of human time, resources, and cognitive processing further complicate matters in the vast sea of publications.

Nevertheless, I believe that new AI implementations in scientific databases and meta-analysis approaches, such as neurosyth, will be employed to test the consistency of our results using both numerical and qualitative criteria. These advancements could help address the aforementioned challenges. Please feel free to reach out to me at [deleted identifiable information], though please note that my response may take some time.

experience: The data loss was not due to a single event but a combination of unforeseen and unexpected circumstances in an era before cloud management was common. Among the events surrounding this, the student's laptop "died", his father overwrote the backup disk with photos, and there was no central storage of the data.
comment: Organize centralized back ups, use the cloud....

experience: NA
comment: I definitely have become a strong advocate of research reproducibility (and open science more genarally) as a result of the experience, and I have become much more systematic and careful in my research. I have also experienced that this may sometimes hinder collaboration with colleagues, because it definitely slows down progress.

experience: All data and manuscript must be carefully processed.

We miscalculated one datapoint out of 24 geochronological ages that were produced in that paper. This was just a inattention error. The corrected paper was published soon after. The journal editor have been very efficient in helping correct this mistake. Not a very interesting case.

The primary author took photo-microscopy pictures. This involved multiple photos of the same tissue culture well, taken from different angles. Later I learned that he kept poor records of those photos so some photos in our final figure turned out to be repetitions of the same well. This was very hard to spot.
comment: The person responsible for poor record keeping is no longer in the lab and we have tightened our photo-microscopy protocols considerably. Hopefully this will prevent recurrence.

experience: NA
NA
comment: We now deposit all plasmids in addgene where they are sequenced immediately prior to publication

experience: No

It was hard to pick just one main cause. Realistically there were failures across multiple of these areas. We were linking subject IDs manually across time instead of using some more automated process, the task was given to an RA or lab manager who clearly wasn't instructed properly on the task and their work was not double-checked by others (and it is unclear if their error resulted from misunderstanding or carelessness), and then the analysis was put on hold for about a year due to medical leave, and upon return files marked as 'final' were treated as final without proper vetting.

It was a horrible experience! Although we could clarify and correct the mistakes (we had wrongly displayed a western blot control band), the journal did not allow us a correction but retracted. Such doing of journals is unnecessary. It put authors into horrible stress and psycho crises, loss of reputation. Unreasonably.
comment: All raw data are strictly kept in a single project folder. All raw data are presented at lab meeting. These files are kept in the paper submission folder. This has much improved data storage.

experience: This was a case where a bioethics journal was quite at sea trying to grapple with statistics (though those recommended by APA) and finally backed away from the paper, though retrospectively, a year after publication
comment: In spite of the retraction the paper has attracted some Researchgate approval with no contrary views expressed

experience: It was a very unfortunate outcome that involved problems at our lab, which we tried to communicate as quickly as possible during the proofing stage, but the editors were unwilling to consider including an explanation of the error and the implications for our findings as well as the larger research environment. It was a highly frustrating experience and our best option was to retract it. I consider it a lost opportunity to help the research community understand some problems with the data and analysis protocol - the paper continues being cited with the mistakes in it and a better option would have been to explain the errors in the actual paper, show which results are robust and help researchers avoid them in the future.
comment: Closer hands-on management of all team members throughout the research process (if more experienced researchers); if time & resources allow: documentation of all steps (including seemingly minor steps that may be taken for granted), careful reading and documenting of all analysis options (a major problem was that the same processing term involved different routines on different analysis platforms and this was not noticed till the paper was in the proofing stage)

The mistake I made was in a secondary data analysis and the codebook had the variable names flipped. For example - the ordering went V1 V2 V3 etc., but at some point had two numbers out of order: V34 V36 V35. I missed this in my coding, causing me to flip my two dependent variables when I recoded them. I am meticulous in my analyses, but I realized how easy it was to make a coding mistake. I'm POSITIVE that this happens WAY more than we know about.

Pay attention to rounding errors and protocol registration on http://clinicaltrials.gov/

I feel that the reviewers did not offer ANY opportunities to correct the errors, nor did they take into consideration the fact that I contacted them to correct something I ALONE noticed as an error. As a new scholar at the time, I did not imagine that the response would be to retract the paper, and the retraction shows up as the only retraction in my bibliography database of 20,000 or more references. So there is also EXTREME shame, stigma, and embarrassment  associated with the fallout. It has forever changed my career trajectory.
comment: What I have learned, sadly, and what I teach my students now is to remain staunchly defensive of anything you are lucky enough to get published. Never cast doubt on any of your conclusions, and never admit fault or mistake. Way to go!

comment: The lessons I learnt was that to double double double check every detail of the coding and to have a good documentation management to make everything clear to stop and continue and easier for others to double check.

comment: A better management and planning with experts before starting the work would help in avoiding errors.

experience: I feel that there is not a universally accepted protocol in journals, other papers with the same mistakes as ours were ammended or corrected, but not retracted. We collaborated with the jorunal even generating new data to reproduce the conflicting data but after an extremely long period with no input from the journal our paper was retracted.
comment: Check the data over and over

experience: The paper was re-published with the correct statistics. Actually the Results became statistically significant.

This was the hardest issue in my academic life ,

comment:
The lessons are :
1. Don't involve an author who is short of adequate knowledge of publication process, the statistics and commitment to review and criticize the work ,
2. Consult professional statistician to check the tests and data use

we have reproduced much of the work and carried that forward to a most interesting paper - on another topic though - t

The first author is suffering an eye surgery when he provides the manuscript for his master degree graduation, due to short of inadequate training and the complex meta data, four wrong sequence names were input wrongly, with one of number reversed fore and after, one wrong accession of bacteria, one identical sequence with another but maybe from one sample at a different part, one can't be defined wrong. experience: My retraction was not due to data management error. It was due to an abusive relationship I had with my supervisor who initially did not want to be on the paper and allowed me to proceed, and later felt furious that I succeeded without him. He threatened me to retract the paper or face dismissal from from PhD scholarship and studies.
comment: My retraction remains one of the hardest points in my academic career. It was a show of power by those in authority. My email is [deleted identifiable information] for more

experience: There are vigilante scientists now that comb through data abs look for mistakes. Honest mistakes are no longer even considered to be honest or accidental.
comment: Happy to talk about everything but this entire process has been such a nightmare and what is even more frustrating is that the paper is correct. The mistake is in an extra file that could have been corrected.

experience:
1) Do not trust the published literature. My retracted article was a compilation of data from the literature. It turns out, some of the data in the compilation are erroneous. The error simply propagated through to the compilation and analyses.
2) Be aware that when you publish in a high-impact journal, the 'bad side' of academia becomes the worst side. The language and tone of the original [deleted identifiable information] paper [deleted identifiable information] were too unpalatable that the journal Nature itself would not consider to publish it unless and until they rewrote. Some people are just too full of themselves and are determined to humiliate you more than necessary.
3) Do not trust your co-author. I asked my co-author (who happens to be my PhD supervisor) to invite more co-authors with the relevant skills and expertise, and also to double check my work. But my co-author disapproved. He wanted the paper to be a two-authored paper, i.e., I and him.
comment:

experience: In many cases, it would likely be more appropriate to publish a corrigendum instead of a retraction, as the error often only pertains to a small part of the results. However, in the current climate of a massive manuscript backlog, editors clearly prefer retraction, which leads to the loss of a great deal of valuable results. Publishing these results in a new article can be challenging, as referees and editors incorrectly argue that these results have been previously published (in the retracted article).
the retraction was made in order to improve the overall manuscript and rebuild a total new statistical correct work
NA

We voluntarily retracted the article as the significant effects reported were related to a measure only tangential to the effect of interest. This of course had an impact on the global interpretation of the findings. Best course of action seemed to be retraction rather than an erratum.
comment: The error probably should have been caught in the review process as the descriptive summary data did not clearly align with values consistent with volumetrics. However, we overlooked this and reviewers did not notice this either. We only figured it out during an attempt at replicating the effect and found lower than expected correlations between the two datasets.

experience: It is important to double check your statistics by all co-authors and two statisticians (if possible) to ensure your work is credible.
